oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Roger Cook Interview by John Lomax III
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: The recording is an interview of Roger Cook by John Lomax III. The interview takes place on 1-14-81.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Roger Cook
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: Side One - (0:01) -- Introduction by John Lomax. (0:17) -- John Lomax asks about the recordings Roger Cook made with Cowboy Jack Clement. (0:48) -- Roger Cook describes making a demo that Cowboy Jack Clement eventually heard and took interest in. This record began a dialogue between Jack Clement and Roger Cook. (2:10) -- Roger Cook describes the personnel when working with Cowboy Jack Clement. (3:16) -- Roger Cook mentions he's a fan of Allen Reynolds and Bob McDill's songwriting. (4:38) -- Roger Cook mentions cutting the Don Williams song "I Believe In You." (5:26) -- Roger Cook speaks about Cowboy Jack Clement's enthusiasm about the song "Living In These Troubled Times." (5:47) -- John Lomax asks Roger Cook to reflect on his career as a vocalist/performer. (8:00) -- Roger Cook mentions being called by Roger Greenaway, leader of a group named "The Kestrels." Roger Cook joined the group on the road for about six months. Roger Cook mentions co-writing the tune "You Got Your Troubles, I've Got Mine" with Roger Greenaway. (9:38) -- Roger Cook mentions recording with George Martin. (11:15) -- Roger Cook describes joining a band named "Blue Mink." (12:44) -- Roger Cook mentions recording the song "Today I Killed A Man I Didn't Know," with an artist named John Burgess. (13:40) -- Roger Cook speaks about leaving the UK and coming to the United States. (14:50) -- John Lomax asks Roger Cook about his sales figures. (15:28) -- Roger Cook mentions Warner Brothers declining his album "Alright." (16:46) -- Roger Cook discusses the emotional impact of his album being rejected by Warner Brothers. (18:00) -- Roger Cook mentions the thoughtfulness of songwriters in Nashville. (19:03) -- John Lomax asks Roger Cook about his additional hits as a writer. (20:25) -- John Lomax asks Roger Cook about working with The Hollies. (21:32) -- John Lomax asks Roger Cook about his songs that have charted in the top five. (25:29) -- Roger Cook mentions the despair as a songwriter of having successful hits then a dry spell. (27:31) -- John Lomax asks Roger Cook about his method of writing lyrics. (29:17) -- Roger Cook mentions that most skilled musicians in Nashville compose with the Nashville number system.
